question: HTML stands for Hyper Text Language.
Browsers display the HTML tags when rendering the content of the page.
The <!DOCTYPE html> declaration defines the document to be HTML5.
The <head> element is the root element of an HTML page.
Heading elements goes from h1 to h4, h1 is the biggest and h4 is the smallest.
The alt attribute is useful in case the user cannot view the image.
The <header> element represents a container for introductory content or a set of navigational links.
You can only have one <header> elements in one document.
A <header> tag can be placed within a <footer>, <address> or another <header> element.
The <footer> element tag defines a footer for a document or section.
You can have several <footer> elements in one document.
The <nav> tag defines a set of navigation links.
All links of a document should be inside a <nav> element.
The <nav> element is intended only for major block of navigation links.
The <blockquote> tag specifies a section that is quoted from another source.
The default display value for <blockquote> is inline-block. With a margin-top, margin-bottom of 1em. And margin-left, margin-right of 40px.
The <section> tag defines sections in a document, such as chapters, headers, footers, or any other sections of the document.
The default display value for <section> is inline.
You can have only 2 sections in a page.
A section may contain a header, a footer and other sections.
The <details> tag specifies additional details that the user can view or hide on demand.
The <details> tag can be used to create an interactive widget that the user can open and close.
Any sort of content can be put inside the <details> tag.
The content of a <details> element should be visible unless the close attribute is set.
The <summary> tag defines a visible heading for the <details> element. The heading can be clicked to view/hide the details.
The <main> tag specifies the main content of a <section> element.
The <summary> tag defines a visible heading for the <details> element. The heading can be clicked to view/hide the details.

The content inside the <main> element could be duplicated in a document. It could contain any content that is repeated across documents such as sidebars, navigation links, copyright information, site logos, and search forms.
The <main> element must NOT be a descendant of an <article>, <aside>, <footer>, <header>, or <nav> element.
There must not be more than one <main> element in a document.
The <input type="date"> is used for input fields that should contain date and time.
Depending on the browser support, a date picker can show up in the input field.
Min and max attributes to add restrictions to input of type date.
The <input type="month"> allow users to select a month and year in the format yyyy-mm
The <input type="week"> allows users to select a week and year in the format yyyy-Wnn
The <input type="time"> allows users to select a time (no time zone).
The user can enter the time in the order hours, seconds, minutes and fraction of a second.
The HTML5 specification indicates thata time must have two digits for hour, followed by a colon (:) and two digits representing the minute.
The <input type="email"> is used for input fields that should contain an e-mail address. Ther user can enter a list of emails separated by commas (if the many attribute is specified).
HTML5 does check whether an e-mail address entered by the user exists, also validates that the e-mail address is in the proper format.
Depending on browser support, the e-mail address can be automatically validated when submitted.
The <input type="number"> defines a numeric input field. It enables the user to enter a numerical value. Mobile browsers typically display a numeric keypad for this input type.
You can set restrictions on what numbers are accepted, and how they are incremented.
The min attribute sets the minimum valid number, and the max attribute sets the maximum valid number. The step attribute determines the increment in which the numbers increase.
The value attribute sets the selected value by the user in the form for an input of type number.
The <input type="range"> defines a control for entering a number whose exact value is not important (like a slider control).
You can set restrictions on what numbers are accepted, and how they are incremented in an input of type range.

The range input type is inherently self-validating when it is rendered by the browser as a slider control, because the user is unable to move the slider outside the bounds of the minimum or maximum values.
The <input type="tel"> is used for input fields that should contain a telephone number from the local region.
The tel type is currently only supported in Safari 8. And all other browsers render the tel input type as a text field.
To ensure that the user enters a phone number in a proper format, it is recommended to use the pattern attribute since phone numbers length vary greatlty based on the location.
The pattern attribute in an input of type tel uses a regular expession to determine whether the number is in the correct format.
The <input type="url"> is used for input fields that should contain a URL address.
Depending on browser support, the url field can be automatically validated when submitted.
The input type url is rendered as a text field, the proper format is http://www.domain.com .
HTML5 does check whether the URL entered is valid; but it does not validate that the URL entered is in the proper format.
